content.webTitle: Labor demands Dutton shed more light on media leak over medevac bill

fields.headline: Labor demands Dutton shed more light on media leak over medevac bill
fields.bodyText: Federal Labor has demanded that home affairs minister Peter Dutton explain whether he or his office were involved in leaking national security advice during a political storm over Nauru and Manus Island medical evacuations. The Australian federal police announced late on Friday afternoon they had dropped their investigation into how the security briefing was leaked to the media. The leaked advice, reported in the Australian, came during a heated political debate in February over the medical transfer bill, which ultimately passed parliament against the government’s wishes. Labor leader Anthony Albanese said Dutton needed to clarify whether he or his office had anything to do with the leak. Albanese said he did not know who was behind the leak but there were curious circumstances around the timing. “Quite clearly that sort of national security advice wasn’t circulating around the [Parliament] on Post-it notes,” he told reporters in Sydney on Saturday. “The leak [was] on the front page of the newspaper. Peter Dutton gave an interview on the record where he spoke about that national security advice on that day. That was entirely inappropriate for him to do so and he did so too in order to secure a political advantage,” he said. The newspaper report quoting home affairs department advice earned an extraordinary rebuke from Australia’s top spy chief for misrepresenting the advice as coming from Asio. The federal police received a referral from the home affairs department on 7 February to investigate the alleged unauthorised disclosure of protected information. A spokeswoman said it had been assessed according to standard protocols. “Due to the limited prospects of identifying a suspect, it was not accepted for investigation,” an AFP spokeswoman said in a statement. “The AFP considers this matter finalised.” Labor’s home affairs spokeswoman, Kristina Keneally, said the decision not to investigate the leak was an “absolutely breathtaking development”. “In light of this week’s media raids, many Australian citizens and media outlets will have questions about why some leaks of classified information lead to raids and other leaks do not,” Keneally said. Keneally said a perception of bias was being created whereby only leaks that embarrassed the government were investigated with rigour. “There is that very real perception of bias and interference, and that problem lies with the government,” she told reporters in Sydney. The federal police have been under fire this week after two days of unprecedented media raids. Officers raided the home of News Corp Australia journalist Annika Smethurst investigating the publication of a leaked proposal to allow government spying on Australians. Then the ABC was targeted over a series of articles the broadcaster ran in 2017 into the clandestine operations of Australian special forces in Afghanistan. The ABC’s chair, Ita Buttrose, has said raids by the federal police on its headquarters were “designed to intimidate” and warned the government she would fight “any attempts to muzzle” the national broadcaster. The former journalist and publisher said she had registered her “grave concern” about the raids on the ABC and News Corp over two days and would not countenance any interference with the public’s right to know. “An untrammeled media is important to the public discourse and to democracy,” Buttrose said. “It is the way in which Australian citizens are kept informed about the world and its impact on their daily lives.”
